Dear Jason Lheureux:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 03/30/2025 at around 6:16 pm, Youth A, Staff 1 and two other
residents were in the north hallway of the unit sheltering in place
due to a tornado/thunderstorm warning. Youth A and Staff 1 were
shouting at each other each.
Youth A tried to walk around Staff 1, but Staff 1 stepped in his
way, which caused them to contact each other. Staff 1 then
grabbed Youth A by his shirt collar. As pushing and a struggle
took place, Staff 1 pushed Youth A against a wall and then to the
floor. Staff 1 held him on the floor and was standing over him with
his hands still gripped onto Youth A's shirt collar. Supervisor tried
to separate them and told them to stop. Once Youth A was on the
floor, Staff 1 was instructed several times to let Youth A go. The
two of them still struggled and then Youth A, Staff 1 and
Supervisor got back to their feet. Supervisor was able to get a
hold of Youth A. Supervisor had to tell Staff 1 several more times
to let Youth A go. He did so at that time. Staff 1 was told to leave
the north hallway, and he did. Youth A was not injured.
Investigation
Supervisor was interviewed via phone on 4/1/2025. He
reported the incident took place in the bedroom hallway where the
youth had taken shelter during a storm warning. He also reported
standing in a position where he was able to observe the hallway
the incident took place in and a second hallway with youth and
another staff were sheltering. He reported overhearing yelling from
the hallway with Staff 1 and Youth A and went into the hallway to
investigate. He observed Youth A attempting to get around Staff 1
and Staff 1 stepping in Youth A’s way in a blocking move. As there
was contact between Staff 1 and Youth A, Staff 1 grabbed Youth
A by the collar of Youth A’s hoddie with both hands. Several
times, Supervisor told Staff 1 to let go of Youth A. Youth A was
trying to push away when Staff 1 pushed Youth A against the wall.
Supervisor reported trying to separate Staff 1 from Youth A when
“we went to the floor”. Staff 1 continued to hold Youth A by the
collar and Supervisor continued to yell “let him go”. He also
2

reported once all three were able to stand again, he told Staff 1 to
let go of Youth A 3-4 times before Staff 1 let go and left the area.
Supervisor placed Youth A in a standing one-person hold but
quickly let go of Youth A. He reported Youth A then sat on the
floor and Supervisor sat next to Youth A. He also reported Staff 1
used a prohibited restraint technique by grabbing Youth A by the
collar and pushing Youth A against the wall. He reported
observing no marks or injuries on Youth A and when Youth A was
observed by Law Enforcement the next day, they reported no
injuries. He also reported Staff 1 has been employed for 2-3
weeks and has no issues with Staff 1 when observing Staff 1
working with any of the youth.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/3/2025. Youth B reported being in the hallway during the
sheltering for the storm and when the incident occurred. Youth B
reported Youth A was trying to attack Youth B and Staff 1 stopped
Youth A from getting to Youth B. Youth B reported not seeing how
Staff 1 stopped Youth A other than standing in front of Youth A.
Youth B also reported going back into his room just as the incident
began. Youth B reported being the only other youth in the hallway
because the other youth were refusing to come out of their
bedrooms. Youth B also reported feeling safe at the facility and
staff will intervene when other youth become aggressive.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/3/2025. Youth C reported being present in his bedroom when
hearing Youth A and Staff 1 argue in the hallway. Youth C also
reported coming out of the bedroom and observing Youth A trying
to hit Youth B. Youth C reported Staff 1 didn’t want Youth A to hit
Youth B so Staff 1 blocked Youth A from getting to Youth B before
Youth C went back into his bedroom. Youth C reported observing
Youth A and Staff 1 fall to the floor but was unsure why they fell to
the floor. Youth C also reported feeling safe at the facility.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/3/2025. He reported Staff 1 has not been working at the facility
since Sunday because Staff 1 was placed on administration leave
until this investigation ended. Staff 1 is currently cleared to return
to work. He also reported Youth A and Youth B have a history
from being placed together at a past CCI. He reported not
receiving much history of Youth A prior to placement but since
learning more about issues between Youth A and Youth B, Youth
B is being moved to the other hallway.
3

Foster Care Worker was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 4/3/2025. He reported receiving Youth A on his
caseload approximately 4 months ago and has no concerns with
Youth A’s current placement. He also reported the facility shared
the incident that occurred on 3/30/25 with him the next day.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/3/2025. Youth A refused to verify his birthday and was unable to
identify how long he has been in his current placement. Youth A
had just returned from the hospital following an incident where
several staff were injured when Youth A became dysregulated.
Youth A reported not wanting to talk about the incident on 3/30/25
other than to report, he was scared and confused. Youth A
reported feeling uncomfortable around others having fun and is
very depressed but at a much higher level than anyone knows.
Youth A reported the incident on 3/30/25 was all his fault and he
has nothing more to say about it. Youth A reported feeling safe at
the facility.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 4/7/2025.
He reported remembering the incident outlined in the allegation.
He also reported Youth A began the shift upset because Youth A
believed his “grounding” (reduction in privileges) should have
been removed. He reported when the tornado warning began,
Supervisor sent the youth to their rooms and Youth A came out of
his room in defiance of the direction. He also reported Supervisor
directed Staff 1 to the hallway for supervision of the youth and
Staff 2 into the other hallway. Staff 1 reported when Youth A sat
on the floor in the hallway, Youth B was also sitting in the hallway.
Youth B took off his shoes and began to hit the floor with the
shoes (making a beat). Staff 1 reported Youth A began to glare at
Youth B and asked Youth B to stop making the noise. Staff 1
reported repositioning himself between Youth A and Youth B.
Youth B ignored Youth A and continued to hit the floor with his
shoe. Staff 1 reported Youth A stood up and attempted to get past
Staff 1 and came “with force” at Staff 1. Staff 1 reported facing
Youth A and falling backwards as Youth A ran into Staff 1. Staff 1
reported grabbing Youth A’s sweatshirt while holding Youth A at
arm’s length. Staff 1 reported Youth A was fighting to get around
Staff 1 and get to Youth B. Staff 1 reported Supervisor had just
entered the room and told Staff 1 to let go of Youth A without
aiding. Staff 1 reported regaining his hold on Youth A, Staff 1 had
to push Youth A backwards causing Youth A to hit the wall. Once
letting go of Youth A, Staff 1 left the room and last heard
Supervisor speaking to Youth A.
4

Documents Reviewed:
Wedgwood Christian Services Significant Event Report dated
3/30/25 @ 6:16 pm. This report documents Youth A, Staff 1, and
Supervisor as the individuals involved in the incident outlined in
the allegations. This document indicates Youth A was in the
hallway with Staff 1 because they were sheltering in place during
a storm. As Youth A attempted to get around Staff 1 and go into
the milieu, an argument broke out and Staff 1 was standing in
front of Youth A as Supervisor entered the hallway. Youth A
attempted to push off Staff 1 as Staff 1 grabbed Youth A around
the collar of Youth A’s sweatshirt, pushing Youth A into the wall.
Youth A ended up on the floor with Staff 1 standing over Youth A
still holding the collar of Youth A’s sweatshirt. Supervisor tried
separating Staff 1 and Youth A and once separated, Supervisor
stayed in the hallway to help process the incident and check on
Youth A. Supervisor noted a small spot of blood on Youth A’s lip
and Youth A wanted to go back to Youth A’s room. It is
documented Supervisor contacted the Administration who came to
the facility to speak with Staff 1.
Wedgwood Chrisitan Services Nursing note dated 4/3/2025
for Youth A. There is no documentation of any injury on Youth A.
Wedgwood Christian Services Client Safety Procedures 03-03
dated prior to 2018. This document outlines staff’s responsibility
in providing supervision of youth. It is documented that at least
one staff member is to remain within eyesight and earshot of
youth at all times. It is also documented that youth are never to be
left alone together in a communal space (hallway).
Wedgwood Christian Services Residential Staffing Ratios
Procedures 03-01 dated July 3, 2024. This document outlines
staff’s responsibility when supervising. It is documented that staff
are required to maintain supervision of youth at all times except
when youth are in their individual sleeping rooms or bathrooms. It
is also documented that staff must complete a minimum of 25
hours of training annually.
Wedgwood Christian Services Crisis Management
Procedures 03-17 dated 11/15/24. This document outlines staff’s
response and use of physical management (personal restraint).
Staff are to only use physical management as a last resort to stop
5

imminent danger to self or others. Staff are allowed to use
physical management in an emergency response to protect the
youth or others from aggressive behavior that places the youth or
others at serious threat of violence or injury. When a youth is
physically acting out or becomes physically threatening or
aggressive, staff members may be required to physically intervene
to protect other youth present.
Wedgwood Christian Services Behavior Management
Procedures 03-16 dated 7/3/24. This document outlines that staff
are to use a variety of verbal de-escalation approaches prior to
any physical management. This document also outlines that the
use of physical management should only be employed in the
manner trained and directed by the AEGIS model.
AEGIS approved level 1 holds. These holds were reviewed, and
the 1-person emergency benevolent hold involves staff standing
behind the youth and placing the staff’s left arm under the left arm
of the youth while placing the left hand on the middle of the
youth’s back. The staff then places their right arm under the right
arm of the youth and places the staff’s right hand on the youth’s
shoulder.
HR file for Staff 1 was reviewed. Staff 1 was hired on 2/26/25.
There was no disciplinary action documented in his personnel file,
and he is current on all required training. He completed AEGIS
Crisis Prevention & De-escalation (8hours) on 3/17/2025,
Introduction to Trauma-Informed Care (1 hour) on 3/3/25, Crisis
Management Basics for Paraprofessionals (1 hour) on 2/27/25,
and Communication and conflict Management Skills (45 minutes)
on 2/26/25.
Video Review:
The video recording of the hallway that the incident took place in
was reviewed. This video recording was of the day and time of the
incident with a view looking down the hallway with the door
leading to the milieu on the left. At 6:17:30 Youth A is sitting on
the floor near the entrance to his bedroom, Youth B is sitting
outside of his bedroom in the hallway, and Staff 1 is standing in
between Youth A and Youth B. Both Youth A and Youth B are
several feet apart. At 6:17:51 Youth A stands up and begins to
move down the hallway in the direction of Youth B. Staff 1 stands
in front of Youth A before Youth A attempts to step around Staff 1.
Staff 1 is observed moving sideways to block Youth A’s path
before Staff 1 grabs Youth A’s sweatshirt around Youth A’s collar
6

just a second before Supervisor enters the hallway. At 6:18:41,
Staff 1 appears to push Youth A against the wall before Youth A
falls to the floor. Supervisor appears to attempt to get between
Staff 1 and Youth A. Staff 1 continues to hold Youth A’s sweatshirt
as Youth A is trying to hit Staff 1. As Supervisor gets behind Youth
A, Supervisor begins a single person standing hold as Staff 1
releases and leaves the area. At 16:19:46, Supervisor lets go of
Youth A and Youth A sits on the floor.
Walk-through:
A walk-through was completed at the facility. The facility is well
furnished and maintained. The hallway was also well maintained
and free of any obstacles. All the bedrooms were also well
furnished and clean.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as evidence by interviews
with staff, youth, document reviews, and video recording review.
The video recording clearly shows Staff 1 engaging in a prohibited
physical action against Youth A but there appears to be no malice
or ill intent in Staff 1 actions. There is no audio with the video
recording and the de-escalation techniques used could not be
determined, however, Staff 1 never mentioned using any verbal
des-escalation. Staff 1 appears to be trying to protect Youth B
from Youth A, who is 4-years older and much larger.
Documentation supports that the action taken by Staff 1 was not
approved and prohibited. This also is supported by Supervisor
who was a witness to the event.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered in ensuring new staff are not
placed in a situation that may result in the need for physical
interaction by staff. The supervisor must be aware of the level of
experience the staff have and provide enhanced oversight to
support the staff as much as possible.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2024SIC0001532 8/7/2024, CAP approval 8/23/2024
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
